episode_summary: This episode of "No Such Thing As A Fish" covers a variety of intriguing topics, including the peculiarities of playing snooker on cruise ships, the Cold War competition over metal pressing technology, the historical significance of handwriting styles in 18th century America, and the fascinating phenomenon of the sun's corona being surrounded by a layer of 'moss'.

facts.fact: Snooker games on cruise ships are sometimes played with flat balls.
One of the major battles in the Cold War was to see who was better at squashing metal.
In 18th century America, you could tell a merchant from a lawyer just by looking at their handwriting.
The sun is surrounded by a layer of moss.
